none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from John H. Realow, November 17, 1882
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from John H. Realow, November 17, 1882
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 12 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: A letter from Representative John H. Reagan of Palestine, Texas to Louis L. McInnis at College Station, Texas, dated November 17, 1882, in response to McInnis's request for a copy of the Congressional Globe from 1850-51 containing Senator Grimes's speech on public lands. Reagan apologizes that upon examination he cannot locate the requested volume, though he had believed he possessed it when they previously spoke in Washington. The letter demonstrates the exchange of legislative documents among political colleagues during the post-Reconstruction period.

body.value:
[Header]

House of Representatives,
Palestine, Texas,
Nov. 17th, 1882.

[Body]

Dear Sir;
Your letter of the 14th inst.
is before me in which you requ-
est me to send you the Vol.
of the Congnl Globe of 1850-
51 which contains Senator
Grimes Speech on the public
lands. When you spoke
to me at Washington I sup-
posed I had it, but on
examination I do not find
it. Otherwise it would afford
me pleasure to comply
with your request.

[Footer]

Very respectfully
[Signature] John H. Reagan

Louis L. McInnis Esq
College Station
Texas

**Final Thoughts and Transcription** Okay, here's what I've got. I'm looking at this letter, and it's a pretty straightforward request for a specific volume of the Congressional Globe. First, the letterhead is printed "House of Representatives," but the location is handwritten as "Palestine, Texas," replacing a crossed-out "Washington, D.C." which makes sense given the time and likely the context of the letter's creation. The date is Nov. 17th, 1882. The salutation is "Dear Sir;". The body of the letter is clear. The author, John H. Reagan, is responding to a letter from Louis L. McInnis, who is requesting the volume of the Congressional Globe from 1850-51 containing Senator Grimesâ€™ speech on public lands. Reagan says he thought he had the volume but after searching, it can't be found. He clearly states he'd comply if possible. Now, some words were transcribed to be correct, and a few abbreviations needed careful consideration. "Inst." means "instant", "Congnl" is the abbreviation for Congressional. I am reading this as "Congnl". The signature is "John H. Reagan." The addressee is Louis L. McInnis Esq of College Station, Texas. Here is the transcription: [Header]

House of Representatives,
Palestine, Texas,
Nov. 17th, 1882.

[Body]

Dear Sir;
Your letter of the 14th inst.
is before me in which you requ-
est me to send you the Vol.
of the Congnl Globe of 1850-
51 which contains Senator
Grimes Speech on the public
lands. When you spoke
to me at Washington I sup-
posed I had it, but on
examination I do not find
it. Otherwise it would afford
me pleasure to comply
with your request.

[Footer]

Very respectfully
[Signature] John H. Reagan

Louis L. McInnis Esq
College Station
Texas
